item.title: Key Iran Nuclear Enrichment Site of Natanz Shows No Sign of Breach
item.description: The United Nations atomic watchdog said there’s no indication of increased radiation levels at Iran’s main uranium-enrichment site, an early sign that Israel’s strikes haven’t penetrated the containment layers protecting the Islamic Republic’s nuclear stockpile.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: The Natanz nuclear facility in Iran in January.

item.title: Israel’s Strikes on Iran Are a Challenge to Trump
item.description: Air assault raises serious questions about the US president’s influence over America’s allies
item.dc:creator: Abeer Abu Omar

media:content.media:description: A damaged building following Israeli strikes in Tehran, on June 13. Photographer: Vahid Salemi/AP Photo

item.title: Israeli Strikes Take Out Iran Supreme Leader’s Top Generals
item.description: Israel killed Iran’s top generals in predawn attacks on Friday, paralyzing Tehran’s military decision making in what may prove to be the opening act of a prolonged war.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: 4月13日，穆罕默德·巴盖里于德黑兰。

item.title: What are Israel’s Air Defenses Against Iran’s Missiles, Drones?
item.description: Israel prides itself on having some of the best air defenses in the world, and these billion-dollar systems have been put to the test since the Iran-backed Palestinian group Hamas provoked a new war with Israel in October 2023. Militant organizations supported by Iran have launched rockets, missiles and drones at Israel. Iran itself has struck repeatedly, most recently in June after Israel launched a major attack targeting the Islamic republic’s nuclear facilities and military leadership.
item.dc:creator: Marissa Newman

media:content.media:description: An Iron Dome air defence system near Jerusalem on April 15. Photographer: Menahem Kahana/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: UK Government’s Tax on Private Schools Cleared by London Court
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s controversial tax on private school fees survived a legal challenge in a boost for the policy that was a key plank of the Labour Party’s manifesto at last year’s general election.
item.dc:creator: Upmanyu Trivedi

media:content.media:description: Eton College in Eton, UK.

item.title: South Africa Sues for Damages After Sewage Floods Its US Embassy
item.description: South African diplomats in Washington working to repair frayed relations with President Donald Trump are confronting an additional headache: the nation’s embassy in Washington was inundated by storm water and raw sewage, which has rendered it partially inoperable and disrupted their work.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Embassy of South Africa, Washington. Source: Buyenlarge/Archive Photos

item.title: Regulators Are Harming UK as a Financial Center, Lords Warn
item.description: A culture of risk aversion and mission creep among UK financial regulators is undermining trust and placing costly burdens on banks and insurers, an influential group of parliamentarians found.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Commuters pass the Bank of England, left, and the Royal Exchange, as they make their way to work in London, UK, on Monday, June 2, 2025. At least 10% of the UK's wealthy non-dom population have left the country following tighter tax rules introduced by Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s Labour government, according to a new report authored by a former Treasury economist. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: UN Nuclear Watchdog Says ‘Deeply Concerned’ Over Israeli Strike
item.description: The United Nations atomic watchdog raised alarm about Israel’s overnight strike against Iranian nuclear facilities, saying the attack breaches international legal norms and risks a radiological incident that could cross borders.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi Photographer: Michaela Nagyidaiova/Bloomberg

item.title: Sweden Will Hit New NATO 5% Defense Spending Goal, Premier Says
item.description: Sweden will reach a planned new NATO defense spending target of 5% of GDP, Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson said, joining a string of countries ramping up commitments ahead of a key summit of alliance leaders.
item.dc:creator: Max Ramsay

media:content.media:description: A Swedish Air Force Gripen fighter jet.

item.title: Israel Attacks Iran’s Nuclear Sites in Major Escalation
item.description: Israel launched airstrikes across Iran on Friday morning, targeting nuclear facilities and killing senior military commanders in a major escalation that could spark a broad war in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Patrick Sykes, Marissa Newman, Galit Altstein

item.title: Korea’s Lee Urges Chaebols to Quell Distrust, Hears Trade Fears
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung called on the heads of the country’s largest conglomerates to help restore market trust while hearing out their concerns over the impact of Donald Trump’s tariffs on global trade.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin, Shinhye Kang

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung

item.title: Israel’s Strikes on Iran Raise Shipping Fears Over Chokepoints
item.description: Shipping lines, brokers and analysts are warning of risks to key maritime thoroughfares in the Middle East after Israel’s strikes on Iran, a major escalation in a region vital to global oil supply and trade.
item.dc:creator: Weilun Soon

item.title: Greece’s IPTO Seeks Pay for Delays to €1.9 Billion Subsea Cable
item.description: Greek grid operator IPTO SA is seeking compensation for delays to getting licenses for seabed surveys that are needed to complete what’s set to be one of the world’s largest power links.
item.dc:creator: Paul Tugwell

media:content.media:description: Manousos Manousakis Source: IPTO

item.title: India, US Harden Trade Stance as July Tariff Deadline Nears
item.description: Trade officials from India and the US have hardened their stance on some key issues as they race to conclude an interim deal before higher US tariffs take effect in July, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A container ship docked at the Mundra Port of Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: Israel Disregards Trump With Major Attack on Iran Nuclear Sites
item.description: President Donald Trump had repeatedly urged Israel not to strike Iran’s nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi, Natalia Drozdiak

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump, left, and Benjamin Netanyahu in Washington, DC, on April 7.

item.title: Trump Can Keep Deploying Troops in LA for Now, Court Says
item.description: The Trump administration won a brief reprieve from a judge’s order to pull back on its use of military troops in Los Angeles to deal with protests over the president’s immigration raids.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles on June 8. Photographer: Kyle Grillot/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Security Office Flexes New Power With Hong Kong Probe
item.description: Beijing’s national security office in Hong Kong carried out its first known joint operation with city officials, marking an expansion of China’s direct law enforcement in the financial hub.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: Protestors wave flags outside the Commissioner's Office of China's Foreign Ministry in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, June 29, 2020. The national security law that China could impose on Hong Kong as early as this week won't need to be used if the financial hub's residents avoid crossing certain "red lines," according to Bernard Chan, a top adviser to Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: FTC Weighs Political Neutrality Pledge for Ad Agency Mega-Merger
item.description: Omnicom Group Inc. and Interpublic Group have discussed with US antitrust officials not withholding online advertising for political reasons as a possible condition for winning approval to form the world’s biggest advertising agency, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Josh Sisco

media:content.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The Trump administration dismissed two Democrats on the US Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday, in the latest move by the White House to assert control over US agencies.

item.title: Akazawa Sees a Deal With US Sparing Japan From Higher Car Levies
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator expects a trade deal with the US to spare Tokyo from higher auto tariffs, even if US President Donald Trump decides to increase them against other nations.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa in Washington, DC, on June 6.

item.title: イスラエルによるイラン攻撃と金融市場動向

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from a damaged building in Tehran, Iran, early on June 13. AP Photo

item.title: North Korea Restores Damaged Warship, Plans Two More Next Year
item.description: North Korea said it successfully refloated a 5,000-ton destroyer that suffered damage in a botched launch attempt last month that left it foundering in shallow water, with leader Kim Jong Un vowing to build two more vessels of the same class next year as part of his efforts to boost the country’s naval capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: A satellite image of damaged Choe Hyon-class destroyer docked at the Rajin repair facility on June 8.

item.title: Philippine Ex-Leader Duterte Seeks Release From ICC Detention
item.description: Former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte has requested the International Criminal Court in The Hague for his interim release, three months after he was arrested for alleged crimes against humanity under his controversial war on drugs.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte is seen on a screen in the courtroom during his first appearance before the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague on March 14.

item.title: Trump Urges Iran to Make a Deal ‘Before It’s Too Late’

media:content.media:description: Firefighters at the scene of an explosion at a residential compound in Tehran. Photographer: Vahid Salemi/AP Photo

item.title: Battle Over Sports Betting Threatens to Derail Lula Fiscal Plan
item.description: A fierce lobbying push by sports betting companies is threatening to bring down the Brazilian government’s plan to raise revenues and hit fiscal goals after the lower house speaker backed off support for a deal he helped broker.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: Judge Questions Trump’s Unilateral Power to Deploy Troops in LA
item.description: A federal judge sharply pressed the Trump administration over its authority to deploy the California National Guard to respond to protests in Los Angeles without the consent of the state’s governor.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles, California, US, on Sunday, June 8, 2025. The deployment of National Guard troops by President Donald Trump over the weekend, despite the objections of state and city officials, led to growing friction between local leaders and the administration.

item.title: Xi Plays Long Game on US-China Trade as Trump Seeks Quick Wins
item.description: While Donald Trump hailed the outcome of trade talks in London, Xi Jinping walked away with an understated strategic gain: a negotiating process that buys China time and helps defuse the threat of more harmful tariffs and technology curbs.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - Chinese President Xi Jinping applauds after a joint press conference with Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva (not pictured) at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on May 13, 2025. (Photo by TINGSHU WANG / POOL / AFP) (Photo by TINGSHU WANG/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Police Come Under Attack for Fourth Night in Northern Ireland
item.description: Police came under attack for a fourth consecutive night in Northern Ireland as disorder spread through multiple towns.

media:content.media:description: Youths face police in Portadown, Northern Ireland, on June 12.

item.title: California Senator Handcuffed Outside Noem Briefing in LA
item.description: US Senator Alex Padilla of California was forcibly removed from a press conference and handcuffed after disrupting a media briefing by Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem on the federal immigration crackdown in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, Maxwell Adler, John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: U.S. Sen. Alex Padilla is pushed out of the room as Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem holds a news conference regarding the recent protests in Los Angeles on Thursday, June 12, 2025. (AP Photo/Etienne Laurent)

item.title: Trump Sees Possible ‘Massive Conflict’ Between Israel, Iran
item.description: President Donald Trump said Israel “could very well” strike Iran but that he had advised against an attack while negotiations over Tehran’s nuclear program were ongoing, as the departure of US staff from the region fans concerns about a coming strike.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan, Mario Parker

media:content.media:description: A replica of Iran's Bushehr Nuclear Power Plant in Isfahan, Iran. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Harvard Asks Judge to Bolster Block of Foreign Student Ban
item.description: Lawyers for Harvard University urged a federal judge to ensure that the Trump administration won’t impose alternative restrictions on the school’s enrollment of foreign students after the government’s earlier efforts were blocked.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nations oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House.
